body.p: Validation rules are defined inside a data definition, and allow Makumba to automatically validated form data input.
The general syntax of a validation rule definition is as follows:

section.title: Validation rule name
section.p: The validation rule name is an identifier which should be unique. The exact usage is not yet specified, but it could be used in the future to centralise error messages or provide translations into other languages, etc.

section.title: Validation rule
section.p: The validation rule specifies what should be validated, and can be one of the following
section.source: [range validation | string length | regular expression | comparison]

section.title: Number range rule
section.p: The range definition rule applies for Number types, i.e. int and real. The [validation rule] is defined as:
Using ? allows to keep one parameter unbound, which will default to java.lang.Integer.MIN_VALUE and java.lang.Integer.MAX_VALUE, respectively, i.e. +/- 231-1.
To require that the age needs to be between 12 and 99:
section.source: age%range = [12..99] : Age must be between 12 and 99!
section.p: To define that we need to be at least 5 year old, but without any upper limit:
section.source: age%range = [5..?] : Age must be at least 5!

section.title: String length rule
section.p: The length definition rule is very similar to the range definition, but applies for string types, i.e. char and text. The [validation rule] is defined as:
Using ? allows to keep one parameter unbound, which will default to a minimum length of 0 and a maxium length of 255
To define that the CV needs to be at least 100 characters, define:
section.source: cv%length = [100..?] : CV must be of decent length!

section.title: Regular expression rule
section.p: The string regular expression rule applies for string types, primarily for char, but also for text. The [validation rule] is defined as:
Regular expressions must be valid regular expressions in Java, for more details please refer to the specification and tutorial.
To compare if a field contains a valid e-mail address, define:

p.code: email%matches = .+@.+\.[a-z]+ : Email address is not valid!

section.title: Comparison rule
section.p: This rule allows to compare a field to a constant value or simple function calls.
The following constants are currently available:

tr.td: The current date, time set to 00:00.

section.p: The following functions are currently available:

tr.td:
Constructs a date.
The function takes up to six arguments, for day, month, year, hours, minutes and seconds. If less than six arguments are passed, the missing values will be automatically set to the current date.
$now is available as a constant for the current date value, and + and - operators can be used to modify that value. e.g. date($now,$now,$now - 5) evaluates as the current date 5 years ago.
Converts a string to lower case.
Converts a string to upper case.

section.p: Valid comparison operators are the ones defined in Java:
To compare if someone is at least 15 years old, define the following validation rule:
section.source: minimumAge%compare = birthdate >= date($now,$now,$now - 15) : You have to be at least 15 years old!
section.p: To ensure that a field doesn't contain only lower-case values, define this rule:
section.source: nameNotAllLower%compare = lower(name) != name : Your name must not contain only lower-case letters!
section.p: Two fields can be compared in a similar way
section.source: graduationCheck%compare = birthdate < graduationDate : You cannot finish school before your birthdate!

section.title: Multi-field uniqueness definition
section.p: Similar to the unique field attribute, you can also define multi-field uniqueness contraints. These constraints can even span over several data definitions, if they are related via pointers.
Multi-field uniqueness can be defined as follows
section.source: uniqueAgeEmail%unique = age, email : the combination of age and email must be unique!
section.note:
If the fields are in the same data definition, the uniqueness definition will translate into a database level multi-field key and uniqueness will be enforced there.
Otherwise, Makumba will issue a query checking the uniqueness before new or edit operations.

section.title: Error message
section.p: The error message that will be displayed if the validation fails.
